citation.article-title: Bacteroides pyogenes sp. nov., Bacteroides suis sp. nov., and Bacteroides helcogenes sp. nov., new species from absesses and feces of pigs

p.s: Description of Bacteroides pyogenes sp. nov.
Bacteroides pyogenes (py.o'ge.nes. Gr. n. pyum pus; Gr. v. gennaio produce; M.L. adj. pyogenes pus-producing)
Obligately anaerobic, Gram-negative, non-motile, non-pigmented, non-spore forming rods.
Gram strains of single colonies from agar plates show predominantly short, Gram-negative rods, single or, occasionally, in pairs with longer rods (0.3 to 0.5 μm by 0.5 to 5.0 μm).
After 2 days of incubation surface colonies to opaque, cream to light grey, shiny and smooth.
Usually hemolysis on blood agar plates.
No growth on the surface of blood agar plates incubated in a candle-extinction jar or in an aerobic atmosphere.
Broth cultures are moderately turbid, sometimes with a slight, smooth sediment.
Growth somewhat enhanced in broth with a fermentable carbohydrate.
Best growth at 37°C; not growth at 15°C.
The pH of PYG medium is decreased after good growth to about 5.0.
Strains do not grow well in PYFG-20% bile broths.
Acid is produced from glucose, ribose, mannose, fructose, galactose, lactose, and glycerol.
Some strains ferment sucrose, maltose, cellobiose, melibiose, raffinose, starch, glycogen, inulin, sorbitol, salicin, and amygdalin.
Arabinose, xylose, gum arabic and xylan are not fermented.
Indole is not produced, nitrate is not reduced, gelatin is not hydrolyzed.
Some strains hydrolyze acsculin and starch.
Major amounts of succinic and acetic acids are produced in PYFG broth together with minor amounts of propionic and isobutyric acids.
All the strains are susceptible to penicillin (10 μg/ml).
Seventy percent of the strains are susceptible to cephalothin (10 μg/ml), colistin (10 μg/ml) and erythromycin (60 μg/ml).
The strains of B. pyogenes are divided into four subgroups (subgroups a, b, c, and d) on the basis of fermentation patterns and esculin and starch hydrolysis.
The G+C content of DNA is 46.1-47.6 mol%.
Habitat: swine abscess and feces.
The type strain is DSM 20611 ( = P39-88), isolated from abscess in pig.
